awd_titl_txt: Large Angular Scale Polarization Survey of the Cosmic Microwave Background
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund commissioning and operations of the Cosmology Large Angular Scale Surveyor (CLASS) cosmic microwave background (CMB) polarization experiment located in the Atacama Desert in Chile. The first of two planned telescopes was recently deployed. The main science goal is to detect a polarization signal originating in a theorized rapid inflation of the universe during the first moments of the Big Bang. Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs.  The project also has an integrated program of public outreach to engage the Baltimore public through the annual Johns Hopkins University Physics Fair, the well-established Quarknet program that trains high school teachers, and interactive planetarium shows at Baltimore city schools with large populations of under-represented minorities.

Ultimately, two telescopes will make observations at frequencies of 40, 90, 150, and 220 GHz.  A novel aspect of the CLASS instrumentation is that its first optical element is a variable polarization modulator (wire grid with variable offset from a flat mirror).  The main science goal is to search for the inflationary gravitational wave B-mode polarization signal on angular scales of roughly 10 degrees, associated with the reionization 'bump' in the CMB angular power spectrum. Another science goal is to improve the electron-scattering optical depth of the reionization era to CMB photons by measuring the E-modes associated with the reionization signal.  Development of the telescopes and other instrumentation to conduct the survey has been supported via two previous awards from NSF's Major Research Instrumentation program.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This MSIP award supported the first five years of operations and data analysis for the Cosmology Large Angular Scale Surveyor (CLASS) project, which aims to map the polarization of the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) on the largest angular scales. Through this award, we have achieved significant new large-angular-scale microwave-polarization measurements over three quarters of the sky. We have also made remarkable advances in analyzing this unique dataset. We now succeed in meeting key science benchmarks at 40 GHz. The 40 GHz polarization map recovers the large-scale synchrotron emission from the Galaxy exceptionally well, and its sensitivity surpasses space-based measurements. The expertise gained at 40 GHz has been applied to microwave data at 90, 150, and 220 GHz, which will be used to reach our scientific aims.

While standard processes produce linear polarization in the CMB, intriguing non-standard mechanisms have been proposed that introduce circular polarization. Due to the CLASS telescopes' direct sensitivity to circular polarization and large angular scales, we have set exceptional new limits on circular polarization from the CMB on the largest angular scales (Padilla et al 2020). It is stunning that these CLASS upper limits are orders of magnitude better than the previous state of the art.

A New Observatory

Through this MSIP project, we have created a new stand-alone observing site in the Atacama Desert in the Andes of northern Chile. The site infrastructure includes a control room, labs and high-bay for commissioning and maintaining the CLASS telescopes, essential heavy equipment, and custom software and network to connect all instrumentation and manage data. We have installed two telescope platforms, each of which holds two telescopes. We have built and commissioned three telescopes covering all CLASS observing frequencies (40, 90, 150, and 220 GHz). The three deployed telescopes have been scrupulously characterized for optical, cryogenic, and detector performance, which we have published in several refereed papers (Appel et al. 2019, Xu et al. 2020, Harrington et al. 2021, Dahal et al. 2022, Cleary et al. 2022, Datta et al. 2022). By proactively monitoring and improving the telescopes, our team has gained unique expertise for measuring CMB polarization on the largest angular scales.

Training the Next Generation of Scientists and Engineers

Fifty-one undergraduate students from JHU, Villanova, UCSC (Chile), University of Maryland Baltimore County, and Morgan State University have conducted research on CLASS. They gained experience through instrumentation, analysis, and presentations at scientific conferences. Their research won recognition at the school and national level, and they have gone on to graduate schools, national labs, and industry. 

CLASS has also provided a rigorous and supportive training ground for PhD students. Seventeen graduate students at JHU, U Chile, PUC de Chile, and U Chicago have led their own instrumentation and analysis projects, and published their work in journals and at conferences. Thus CLASS has been a spring board for PhDs to excellent postdoctoral positions at top universities and to high-tech jobs in industry.

The CLASS project has provided career development for postdoctoral researchers. Fourteen postdocs have led subprojects with their own teams of students. In this way they build the skills to lead their own research groups.

Education and Outreach

The CLASS collaboration engaged the community to increase public awareness of science and to foster scientific interests in school-aged children.  CLASS graduate students produced portable planetariums, which were taken to Baltimore city schools, delivering exciting images, stories and discussion of our science to students. Our collaboration also organized activities for the JHU Physics Fair, which attracts 600–800 people annually from the diverse Baltimore community. We used media and interactive experiments to bring the ideas of cosmology and astronomy to the community. 

CLASS professors and postdocs engaged Baltimore-based science teachers through the JHU Quarknet, a summer-time continuing education program. We discussed cosmology and our project with the teachers, providing written and on-line tutorials that they could incorporate into their curriculum. 

We reached a global audience through the CLASS public website, Wikipedia page, and Twitter account. We worked with reporters to publish project developments broadly, including a story on NPR's All Things Considered with a listenership of 40 million.

With an instructional resource specialist and Baltimore high-school physics teachers, we have developed cosmology educational resources for Maryland schools. We made the resources available locally in demonstrations and activities, in particular through the Quarknet program. Our first modules on Hubble expansion and CMB have been successfully piloted in Baltimore and Montgomery County classrooms for two academic years.

Open access to CLASS publications, data, and software is through the CLASS Website and the NASA Legacy Archive for Microwave Background Data Analysis (LAMBDA). The CLASS data will be of great legacy value to the astronomical community given its overlap other large surveys.
